messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Metal-on-metal...
messages.msgSnippet: ... Louis et al- Ideally there is no sword to sword contact but of course it happened. The softer back and core were mainly to absorb the shock of a cut (TO
messages.messageBody:
On Monday, Dec 15, 2003, at 11:12 US/Pacific, Louis wrote:

> Rich,
>
> So, if I am understanding this properly, due to the way in which is the
> blade is tempered -- the majority of the blade being covered in clay,
> with
> only the Hamon edge showing -- the back side of the blade is thus
> softer
> than the edge, allowing the attacking blade to cut into it during a
> block.
> Thus, the attacking edge is spared a chip, as is the defending blade.
>
> Decidedly different from European swordplay.
>
> I appreciate the information, and continue to be fascinated by the many
> differences between European and Japanese swords and swordsmanship.
>
> --Louis
>

Louis et al-
Ideally there is no sword to sword contact but of course it happened.
The softer back and core were mainly to absorb the shock of a cut (TO
something else) and not to spare the attackers blade. Ideally cuts are
anticipated and avoided, "if there is time to block there is time to
cut" or so goes the teaching. Blocks are often hinted at in kata but
not emphasized. When a sword blocks another you get chips in the edge,
cuts along the back, bends, wrinkles,you can actually "shave" chunks
out of the back, cut a sword in half and the heat of impact can
actually fuse the two together, then you are both dead...
-t

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Metal-on-metal...
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Louis,  Actually, the whole blade is covered with clay when tempered, but the cutting edge is covered wiht a thinner layer and clay lines are put down to
messages.messageBody:
Hi Louis, Actually, the whole blade is covered with clay when
tempered, but the cutting edge is covered wiht a thinner layer and
clay lines are put down to form special chacteristics of the hamon.
very difficult.

Check out Yoshindo Yoshihara's "Craft of the japanese Sword" for
great stpe-by-step description.
doug e.
-- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Louis <malklaka2012@s...> wrote:
> Rich,
>
> So, if I am understanding this properly, due to the way in which is
the
> blade is tempered -- the majority of the blade being covered in
clay, with
> only the Hamon edge showing -- the back side of the blade is thus
softer
> than the edge, allowing the attacking blade to cut into it during a
block.
> Thus, the attacking edge is spared a chip, as is the defending
blade.
>
> Decidedly different from European swordplay.
>
> I appreciate the information, and continue to be fascinated by the
many
> differences between European and Japanese swords and swordsmanship.
>
> --Louis
>
>
> On 12/15/03 10:06 AM, "alchemyst" <alchemyst@y...> wrote:
>
> > Louis -
> >
> > Generally there is little metal to metal contact with Japanese
> > swords unlike European fighting styles. When there is, it is
> > normally on the back of the blade as a block to a cut. If
> > there is chipping on the edge, it requires repolishing
> > and possibly reshaping of the blade. If the chip is too deep,
> > that is thru the hamon, the blade is generally considered
> > ruined. Cut marks on the back (mune) or side (shinogi) are
> > usually left alone and some collectors consider them marks
> > of honor.
> >
> > Rich S
> >
> > ------------------------------------------------------------
> > Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@y...
> >
> > The Japanese Sword Index
> > http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Metal-on-metal...
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, So, if I am understanding this properly, due to the way in which is the blade is tempered -- the majority of the blade being covered in clay, with only
messages.messageBody:
Rich,

So, if I am understanding this properly, due to the way in which is the
blade is tempered -- the majority of the blade being covered in clay, with
only the Hamon edge showing -- the back side of the blade is thus softer
than the edge, allowing the attacking blade to cut into it during a block.
Thus, the attacking edge is spared a chip, as is the defending blade.

Decidedly different from European swordplay.

I appreciate the information, and continue to be fascinated by the many
differences between European and Japanese swords and swordsmanship.

--Louis


On 12/15/03 10:06 AM, "alchemyst" <alchemyst@...> wrote:

> Louis -
>
> Generally there is little metal to metal contact with Japanese
> swords unlike European fighting styles. When there is, it is
> normally on the back of the blade as a block to a cut. If
> there is chipping on the edge, it requires repolishing
> and possibly reshaping of the blade. If the chip is too deep,
> that is thru the hamon, the blade is generally considered
> ruined. Cut marks on the back (mune) or side (shinogi) are
> usually left alone and some collectors consider them marks
> of honor.
>
> Rich S
>
> ------------------------------------------------------------
> Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...
>
> The Japanese Sword Index
> http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm

messages.subject: Re: Metal-on-metal...
messages.msgSnippet: Louis - Generally there is little metal to metal contact with Japanese swords unlike European fighting styles. When there is, it is normally on the back of the
messages.messageBody:
Louis -

Generally there is little metal to metal contact with Japanese
swords unlike European fighting styles. When there is, it is
normally on the back of the blade as a block to a cut. If
there is chipping on the edge, it requires repolishing
and possibly reshaping of the blade. If the chip is too deep,
that is thru the hamon, the blade is generally considered
ruined. Cut marks on the back (mune) or side (shinogi) are
usually left alone and some collectors consider them marks
of honor.

Rich S

------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm
http://home.earthlink.net/~steinrl/nihonto.htm
------------------------------------------------------------

messages.subject: Metal-on-metal...
messages.msgSnippet: A quick question for the group: if you go metal-on-metal with two swords of equal hardness, how do you repair the notches in the blade edge? Up until now, I
messages.messageBody:
A quick question for the group: if you go metal-on-metal with two swords of
equal hardness, how do you repair the notches in the blade edge?

Up until now, I have only been involved with broadsword-style swords, and am
new to what I am rapidly realizing is the vastly different world of Japanese
swords. It would seem near impossible to repair the notches in the hardened
edges of such blades.

Am I missing something?

Many Thanks,

--Louis

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba theme
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, This theme tsuba is in the book Sukashi Tsuba in European Collections by Kremers (pg 130).  The example in the book is 3 rd master Tadatora or a student
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
This theme tsuba is in the book Sukashi Tsuba in European Collections by
Kremers (pg 130). The example in the book is 3 rd master Tadatora or a
student of Tadatora, but it goes on to mention that there is a guard of similar
design in Japan that is fifth master. Just though you might want to know.

Lou


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Given the crests and long, spindly legs I they might be herons or egrets. I don't see the fox, just a circle of birds.

Looks Akasaka, too.

Jim

Hi all, I just picked this up, Mid Akasaka I believe. I am curious as to the theme. Is this fluyin gesse turning into a fox ?, and back to the geese again ?, it sort of looks like it's going through some sort of metamorphis to me.

Any clues

Rich
